awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Node:  Upstate NY Alliance for Entrepreneurial Innovation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project by Cornell University will launch a new I-Corps Node centered in Upstate New York. I-Corps NY Node brings together Cornell University as the lead institution, the University of Rochester and Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) as partner institutions. This project will increase the velocity, volume, and success rate of technology startup teams forming in the colleges and universities in the Northeast, including Upstate NY. This new Node will adopt current best-practices in the Node network to grow a network of business mentors for academic inventors, promote lean launchpad principles in research, and expand entrepreneurship education around the region. The Node evaluation team will use iterative evaluation and redesign efforts to ensure the achievement of economic development, education, and workforce development outcomes. The researchers, instructors, mentors, and institutions in this Node will bring new ideas and tools to strengthen the National Innovation Network.

This project will foster the inclusion of I-Corps participants, particularly underrepresented minorities, women, and the disabled in multiple regional I-Corps programs each year. In partnership with RIT's National Technical Institute for the Deaf, the Nation's largest engineering program for the deaf and hard of hearing, the Node will encourage nationwide participation from this underrepresented group. Programs will conclude with showcase events to publicize the teams and their success in regional innovation. This project will leverage a high concentration of academic anchor institutions to improve a moribund regional economy. Upstate NY academic institutions spend over $2.3bn on R&D, an amount that ranks eighth nationwide in state research spending. I-Corps represents an investment in growing a new innovation economy in a part of the country with tremendous assets to build upon and expand.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Upstate New York I-Corps Node (UNY Node) project was established to serve the Upstate New York entrepreneurial ecosystem by providing access to I-Corps courses and mentorship to deep technology researchers and aspiring startup founders at universities throughout the upstate NY region. The UNY Node provided support to universities in nearby states, including West Virginia and Vermont, where I-Corps training was not offered. Major goals of the UNY Node project were: 1) Regional Training. Deliver an innovation-enhancing training program (Regional Courses) based on the curriculum used to support national NSF I-Corps programs. 2) Infrastructure. Develop near-term tools and resources that will impact and expand the benefits of the NIN. 3) Research. Identify and pursue long-term research and development projects to advance innovation by studying collaboration, education, scaling and evaluating practices and outcomes through integration with the innovation ecosystem.


Regional Training. For six years the UNY Node tested, refined, and expanded its regional I-Corps course offerings. In 2017, the Node launched a two-week, in person, ?short course? delivered on campuses of Node partners and other universities in driving distance. In 2019, the Node developed a four-week ?blended learning? course that included asynchronous, self-paced content delivered on a LMS, Zoom-based live class sessions, and set of rubrics to help regional instructors and teams assess fit and readiness for the national I-Corps program. In 2020, with the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, the blended learning course became fully virtual. The virtual model proved to be a powerful tool for making regional courses more accessible to all learners. As the pandemic receded, the virtual model remained popular, especially with rural participants who could not easily attend in-person courses. Since 2021, the UNY Node piloted a hybrid course model combining virtual learning with an in-person trip to a large industry conference or event. Like the virtual model, the hybrid model has been highly beneficial to all learners, especially rural teams who struggle to find enough customers to interview locally. The Node?s regional training curriculum, LMS, and teaching team serve as the foundation of the newly launched IN I-Corps Hub.

Infrastructure. The UNY Node has honed a centralized process and set of tools for scheduling, administering, and conducting regional I-Corps courses at host locations across our widely dispersed geographic region in the northeastern US.  This centralized system comprised of application and data management tools, a robust learning management system (LMS), and a team of virtual TAs, made it easy for new institutions to take part in and use our regional I-Corps course model. It also meant that the Node collected and stored critical data for the regional I-Corps courses centrally, to be used for evaluation and reporting, and for management of participants who applied to I-Corps Teams. To ensure that regional instruction would be delivered with consistency and high quality at every hosting location, the UNY Node developed a multi-faceted regional I-Corps Instructor Training program that combines an asynchronous training course with live cohort meetings, class observations and co-teaching experiences. All UNY regional course instructors were required to complete the course, which included strategies to effectively teach customer discovery methodology and provide ?purposefully direct? feedback to I-Corps participants. The course also focused on how to recognize and disrupt implicit bias and create an inclusive and equitable learning environment. This training program and the regional instructors who have completed it serve as the foundation of the newly launched IN I-Corps Hub.

 

Research. The UNY Node?s Research and Evaluation team, led by the University of Rochester, conducted a five-year study of the Node?s regional course program to assess participants? growth in learning because of participation in the course. This research included a focus on understanding existing diversity at the application and participant stages, building instructional capacity and instructor diversity by training new UNY instructors, and sharing our instructor training course with inclusive teaching practices with Hubs, Nodes and Sites in other regions, and contributing to the field of entrepreneurial education through scholarship. Decisions about how to improve the regional I-Corps course experience were data-driven and validated by the research findings. Two core recommendations guided the creation of the UNY Node?s Instructor Training curriculum: 1) develop regional instructor training on how to combat implicit bias and create an inclusive learning environment; and 2) create a tool for regional teams and their instructors to self-assess national I-Corps Teams program readiness. Since 2020, the UNY Node has shared this I-Corps instructor training with Hubs, Nodes and Sites across the NIN. Additional research recommendations reinforced the Node?s approach to Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Accessibility: 1) support the success of emerging entrepreneurs through active and intentional efforts with an emphasis on inclusion and a sense of belonging, 2) Apply intentional recruitment strategies to diversif

Modified by: Tom Schryver
